importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, marks a tragic event involving a prominent songwriter, highlighting aviation safety issues in general aviation settings.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The crash occurred during a flight that began with a visual approach to runway 7, which took place around the time of a communication failure between the pilot and air traffic control, indicating a critical moment in flight operations.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for his work with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, with no mechanical issues found in the wreckage.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved, but failed to change his radio frequency to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), leading to a loss of communication.
The controller attempted to warn James that he had not changed the frequency, but no further communication occurred.
The plane, a Cirrus SR22T, flew over the runway and executed a left turn before descending into the spiral and crashing.
Brett James was 57 years old at the time of the crash and was flying a single-engine plane, a common setup in general aviation, underscoring the importance of radio protocol and pilot communication.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to announce their position when no air traffic control tower is present.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to the CTAF, resulting in a lost communication link with air traffic control, which played a critical role in the accident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board reported that the Cirrus SR22T he was piloting entered a 'tightening spiral' after failing to change his radio frequency to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite being cleared for a visual approach to runway 7. Air traffic control attempted to warn James that he had not changed the frequency, but no further communication occurred. The NTSB found no mechanical faults in the aircraft. The incident highlights critical risks in general aviation due to communication failures, even in routine flights.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
